app

Class Ocean

  • java.lang.Object
    • app.Ocean

  • public class Ocean
extends java.lang.Object

    This class represents the ocean in the game Battleship. It is a part of the Battleship game application, which is run by the class BattleshipGame.

    This class regularly interacts with class Ship.

    To get started, after instantiation of an object of this class, the instance method placeAllShipsRandomly is invoked in order to place 10 ships in this Ocean: 1 Battleship, 2 Cruisers, 3 Destroyers and 4 Submarines. After that, the Ocean is ready and the game can start.

    Since:
    17th December 2014
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Liran Harary (lharar01, 12837230)

      • getShipInLocation

        public Ship getShipInLocation(int row,
                              int column)

        Returns the Ship in the location sent as arguments (row and column)

        If row and column are outside

        the bounds of the ships array, returns a new Ship to indicate something went wrong.
        Parameters:
        row - Required Ship's row
        column - Required Ship's column
        Returns:
        Ship in required location, or new Ship if location is out of bounds.

      • setShipInLocation

        public boolean setShipInLocation(Ship ship,
                                 int row,
                                 int column)

        Sets the Ship sent as an argument in the row and column sent as arguments; only if the row and column are not outside the bounds of the ships array.

        Returns whether or not the operation was legal and performed.

        Parameters:
        ship - Ship to set in location.
        row - row to set the Ship in.
        column - column to set the Ship in.
        Returns:
        whether or not the operation was legal and performed.

      • placeAllShipsRandomly

        public void placeAllShipsRandomly(boolean testing)
        Randomly places the following Ships (in the following order) in the ocean (in the ships array):
        • 1 Battleship
        • 2 Cruisers
        • 3 Destroyers
        • 4 Submarines
        Parameters:
        testing - Whether or not to turn on testing mode. Testing mode prints the Ships that have been placed, their locations and their orientation.

      • generateShipFleetArray

        private Ship[] generateShipFleetArray()

        Places 10 Ships into the shipArray: 1 Battleship, 2 Cruisers, 3 Destroyers and 4 Submarines.

        Then returns the array.

        Used by placeAllShipsRandomly(boolean)

        Returns:
        shipArray

      • isOccupied

        public boolean isOccupied(int row,
                          int column)
        Returns whether or not the location received as arguments contains a Ship.
        Parameters:
        row - Row to check if is occupied
        column - Column to check if is occupied
        Returns:
        true if the given location contains a ship, false if it does not.

      • shootAt

        public boolean shootAt(int row,
                       int column)

        Shoots at a given row and column in the ocean. This entails:

        • Incrementing shotsFired by 1.
        • Incrementing hitCount by 1 if the given location isOccupied(int, int) and the Ship at the given location is not sunk.
        • Invoking the method shootAt of the Ship at the given location and storing the result in shootResult.
        • Incrementing shipsSunk by 1 if the Ship at the given location is not sunk after shooting it.
        • Returning the shootResult.

        This method has been made to call the relevant Ship's shootAt method, because:

        • For this Ocean's shootAt(int, int) method to know if to increment the shipsSunk or not, it needs to check if the relevant Ship is sunk after its shootAt method has been invoked.
        • It doesn't make much sense for the BattleshipGame class to interact with the Ship class, nor does it make sense for it to have to call 2 different shootAt methods to achieve the one goal of shooting at a Ship
        Parameters:
        row - Row to shoot at in the ocean.
        column - Column to shoot at in the ocean.
        Returns:
        true if the shot hit a part of the relevant Ship AND the Ship is not sunk.

      • print

        public void print()

        Prints the ocean's map with row and column numbers to aid the user.

        The legend of symbols for it is as follows:

        • 'S' indicates a location that has been fired upon and contains a hit but not sunk Ship.
        • '-' indicates a location that has been fired upon and does not contain a real Ship (i.e. is EmptySea).
        • 'x' indicates location containing a sunken Ship.
        • '.' indicates a location that has not been fired upon.

        Utilises printLegend() to print the legend of symbols for the ocean's map.

      • printLegend

        public void printLegend()

        Print the legend of symbols for the ocean's map.

        This method is currently only used by the print() method.
